data: Introduction to the Bushwick Inlet Park History

Bushwick Inlet Park is a 28-acre piece of land that sits along the East River at the juncture of Greenpoint and Williamsburg. The park was created in 2005, a giveback from the City of New York to the residents of North Brooklyn as part of a massive waterfront rezoning that so far has added more than 50,000 new residents to these neighborhoods[WD1] . The design of the park is guided by a master plan design prepared by Donna Walcavage of Stantec and endorsed through a community process in 2007.

When it is completed, Bushwick Inlet Park will be the crown jewel set in the midst of 5 miles of almost continuous waterfront esplanades running from the Wallabout Creek to Newtown Creek. Set between Marsha P. Johnson East River State Park to the south and the Greenpoint Monitor Museum to the north, BIP and its immediate neighbors will provide close to 36 acres of contiguous public open space [WD2] directly on the East River. But almost 20 years after the rezoning, the park is still more of a concept than a reality. As of 2023, less than a third of the park has been constructed, and it was only in the past few years that the City acquired – at great expense – the final piece of the puzzle that makes up Bushwick Inlet Park. Completion of the full park is likely decades away.
The Bushwick Inlet Park “puzzle” consists of 5 pieces of property[WD3] , acquired at various times between 2007 and 2016 and scheduled to be developed in phases.
At the north end of the park, wrapping the inlet itself on three sides is the 2-acre Motiva site, the only part of the park within Greenpoint.
On the south side of the inlet is the 10.4-acre Bayside Oil site, whose large oil tanks were a stark reminder of the environmental degradation of waterfront until their demolition in 2019.

South of the Bayside property on Kent Avenue is a 2-acre, half-block parcel known as 50 Kent Avenue that opened in 2021 as the newest piece of green space to be added to the Park. The western half of this block and the full block to the south comprise the CitiStorage property, 8.5 acres in total.
The southernmost block of Bushwick Inlet Park is the 4.6-acre soccer field site, also home to the North Brooklyn Parks headquarter/community house.
North Brooklyn Parks headquarters and community house

The Bushwick Inlet Park History Project tells the story of Bushwick Inlet Park, Bushwick Creek and the surrounding neighborhoods of Williamsburg and Greenpoint through historic maps and photographs. The history is divided into five eras, covering pre-European contact through the present day and beyond. To navigate this story, start by clicking on one of the era buttons at the left of the screen (or top of the screen if you are viewing on a handheld device). You can also use the timeline at the bottom of the page, which will expand to show the chapters of each era.

Explore the history of the sites

This project uses many historic maps in addition to photographs and other resources to tell the history of Bushwick Creek and Bushwick Inlet Park. Historic maps were georeferenced to align with current-day geographies. Georeferencing is particularly tricky when it comes to shorelines, creeks and water features, which shift over time and may not have been as accurately mapped as more terrestrial features were.

Use the sidebar chapter selector and the timeline below to explore content about Bushwick Inlet through five historical eras. Each era is represented by a circle at the bottom of the screen. Each era has multiple chapters -- select an era and hover over the chapter dots to reveal the story location on the era map.

Note on geographies:

Much of what would someday be Bushwick Inlet Park was underwater. The high-water line south of the inlet was located just west of Kent Avenue, while north of the inlet the high-water line was east of West Street. The mouth of the inlet extended from North 12th Street to Meserole Avenue, and the inlet itself extended inland along the line of North 15th Street to Nassau Avenue and Banker Street (Banker’s Anchor).

Introduction

400 years ago, much of what would someday be Bushwick Inlet Park was underwater. The high-water line south of the inlet was located just west of Kent Avenue, while north of the inlet the high-water line was east of West Street. The mouth of the inlet extended from North 12th Street to Meserole Avenue, and the inlet itself extended inland along the line of North 15th Street to Nassau Avenue and Banker Street (Banker’s Anchor).

In 1855, the town of Bushwick (which at that time included all of Greenpoint) and the (newly minted) City of Williamsburgh became part of the City of Brooklyn. For the 235 years prior to the merger, what we now call North Brooklyn existed as a physically and politically separate place, growing from settlements of a few dozen families to (in the case of Williamsburgh) a city of over 50,000 people. Most of that growth happened in the 30 or so years from 1825 to 1855 – for the two centuries prior to that Williamsburg, Greenpoint and Bushwick were thinly populated agricultural communities heavily reliant on enslaved labor serving the city of New York across the East River.

In 1855, the town of Bushwick (which at that time included all of Greenpoint) and the (newly minted) City of Williamsburgh became part of the City of Brooklyn. For the 235 years prior to the merger, what we now call North Brooklyn existed as a physically and politically separate place, growing from settlements of a few dozen families to (in the case of Williamsburgh) a city of over 50,000 people. Most of that growth happened in the 30 or so years from 1825 to 1855 – for the two centuries prior to that Williamsburg, Greenpoint and Bushwick were thinly populated agricultural communities heavily reliant on enslaved labor serving the city of New York across the East River.

First envisioned as a suburb for growing Manhattan across the river, Williamsburgh quickly became a center for manufacture. In the 1850s, two industries that would transform north Brooklyn – sugar refining and petroleum distillation – were established on the Williamsburgh waterfront.

By 1900, the Williamsburg and Greenpoint waterfronts were fully given over to industrial and distribution operations. At the head of Manhattan Avenue was the Chelsea Manufacturing Co., maker of ropes and ships stores (and a successor to the early history of rope walks). South of there was the Gleason-Tiebot Glass Works (now Glasserie). Clay Street south to Java Street was mostly given over to lumber yards, bringing bulk wood products in via the waterfront for distribution throughout the city. These yards continued in operation through the late 20th century and much of the property is now developed as Greenpoint Landing. South of Greenpoint Avenue was the American Manufacturing Company (better known now as Greenpoint Terminal Market), another rope and ship’s stores manufacturing company. And south of there was the Continental Iron Works, still in operation in 1900. South of the inlet in Williamsburg, Standard Oil and the Williamsburg Gas Light Company continued to operate as described above. Cooperages (barrel factories – barrels were the preferred containers for bulk sugar and other products), distilleries, coal pockets (coal transfer stations) and sugar refineries occupied the waterfront south of North 4th Street. The American Sugar Refining Company (previously Havemeyers, later Domino Sugar) occupied the blocks from Grand Street to South 6th Street (the Williamsburg Bridge was under construction at this time); Mollenhauer’s sugar refinery was located between South 7thStreet and Division Avenue.

In 1855 the City of Williamsburgh and the Town of Bushwick (which still included Greenpoint) were merged into the City of Brooklyn and collectively came to be known as the Eastern District of Brooklyn. First envisioned as a suburb for growing Manhattan across the river, Williamsburgh quickly became a center for manufacturing. In the 1850s and 1860s, two industries – sugar refining and petroleum distillation – joined shipbuilding and ironworks on the Williamsburgh and Greenpoint waterfronts and transformed north Brooklyn into an industrial powerhouse.

At the head of Manhattan Avenue was the Chelsea Manufacturing Co., maker of ropes and ships stores (and a successor to the early history of rope walks). Clay Street south to Java Street was mostly given over to lumber yards, bringing bulk wood products in via the waterfront for distribution throughout the city. These yards continued in operation through the late 20th century and much of the property is now developed as Greenpoint Landing. South of Greenpoint Avenue was the American Manufacturing Company (better known now as Greenpoint Terminal Market), another rope and ship’s stores manufacturing company. And south of there was the Continental Iron Works. South of the inlet in Williamsburg, Standard Oil and the Williamsburg Gas Light Company continued to operate as described above. Cooperages (barrel factories – barrels were the preferred containers for bulk sugar and other products), distilleries, coal pockets (coal transfer stations) and sugar refineries occupied the waterfront from North 4th Street to Division Avenue. The American Sugar Refining Company (previously Havemeyers & Elder, later Domino Sugar) occupied the blocks from Grand Street to South 6th Street (with the Williamsburg Bridge being under construction at this time); Mollenhauer’s sugar refinery was located between South 7th Street and Division Avenue.

Bushwick Inlet Park today stands as a legacy of community action (and municipal inaction). As industry faded in the post-World War II era, local activists began fighting to reclaim the waterfront for the community. El Puente spearheaded the creation of Grand Ferry Park at the foot of Grand Street – the first public open space on the North Brooklyn waterfront. NAG – Neighbors Against Garbage - battled a Giuliani-era plan to turn the Northside waterfront into a massive waste transfer station. GWAPP – Greenpoint-Williamsburg Against the Power Plant - fought for years to stop the construction of a huge power plant on the inlet.

The 2005 rezoning put Bushwick Inlet Park on the map but did not create a park. The land was still in private hands. Residential construction quickly exploded along the waterfront and upland, but parks construction did not keep pace. Bushwick Inlet Park today stands as a legacy of community action (and municipal inaction).

2007 was a very active year for waterfront parks. That was the year that Friends of Bushwick Inlet Park was organized (although the organization did really become active until four or five years later).

More important, in 2007, the Department of Parks completed a master plan for the Williamsburg and Greenpoint waterfronts, including a master plan for Bushwick Inlet. Developed by landscape architect Donna Walcalvage and Stantec Engineering, the BIP master plan identifies use areas of the park – such as active and passive recreation areas – and guides the design development of each parcel as it comes online. The master plan was developed as part of a broad community engagement process and reflects the uses and features prioritized during that process. The master plan remains the guiding star for the development of Bushwick Inlet Park to this day.

The 2005 rezoning and the Bushwick Inlet Park master plan originally included a 1-acre site at the north side of Bushwick Inlet (to the west of the Motiva site) that is owned by the Greenpoint Monitor Museum. The property was donated to the Museum in 2003 by Motiva Enterprises, a joint venture of Shell Oil and Saudi Aramco, which had acquired the property from Texaco. In early plans for Bushwick Inlet Park, the Monitor Museum site is included as part of the park and the property is still mapped as parkland, however the City has since acknowledged that it has no intention of acquiring the Museum parcel through eminent domain.
